Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The response of the terrestrial carbon cycle to climate change since LGM as recorded in Bengal Fan sediments
Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs plan to establish the effects of climate change on terrestrial organic carbon (OC) dynamics in the Ganges-Brahmaputra/Bengal Fan system since the Last Glacial Maximum. Sub-millennial resolution records of sediment and OC burial in the Bengal Fan will be developed using inorganic proxies of sediment composition and delivery and paired stable isotope/radiocarbon measurements. These records will enable reconstructions of variations in monsoon strength, paleo-vegetation, and OC residence time, providing insight into the relationships between climate change, geomorphic response, vascular plant biomarkers, and terrestrial OC dynamics in the Bengal Fan. The proposed work will support two early-career scientists, and will train two undergraduate students from underrepresented minority groups. The project will strengthen international collaborative ties through data sharing and synthesis efforts with Swiss and German researchers.

Institution.Name: College of William & Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science

POR.DRECONTENT:
The physical and chemical weathering of rocks - especially those in high elevation mountain ranges - along with the export of carbon locked in organic matter (for example, soil and vegetation) to the coastal ocean is one of the primary mechanisms by which atmospheric CO2 is transferred to, and sequestered in, the world’s oceans. The efficiency by which these processes act has long been mechanistically linked to climate: increased atmospheric CO2 sequestration under warm and/or wet conditions acts as a negative feedback to climate by drawing more CO2 out of the atmosphere and causing cooling. These processes act together to regulate climate over thousands to millions of years.

This study sought to quantify these feedbacks between climate change and, rock weathering, and organic carbon production and export in the period following the Last Glacial Maximum (~24,000 years ago). It was focused on the Ganges-Brahmaputra drainage basin, the source of the world’s largest fluvial sediment load, and the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta and Bengal Fan, the depocenter for these rivers and the world’s largest delta and largest reservoir of terrigenous sediments. We reconstructed climate (specifically, Indian summer monsoon strength) and vegetation (grasses vs. forest) changes in the Ganges-Brahmaputra basin since the Last Glacial Maximum using sediment samples and organic matter from series of sediment cores from the channel-levee system of the Bengal Fan. We also developed records of the source of those sediments from within the Ganges-Brahmaputra basin as well as the age of the terrestrial organic matter buried with those sediments.

Our study found that, during the late glacial, cooler, drier conditions prevailed over the northern Bay of Bengal, Indo-Gangetic plain and across the Himalaya. Increasing CO2 concentrations during the latest Pleistocene and through the middle Holocene (13,000 to 6000 years ago) coincided to increases in mean effective moisture and monsoonal activity in the Ganges-Brahmaputra basin. This coincided with a large decline of C4 plants (grasses), shifting the drainage basin towards the forest-dominated ecosystem found in the Common Era. We also found that there were higher rates of sediment export from the High Himalayas during the latest Pleistocene and early Holocene. Finally, we demonstrate that the burial of organic carbon in the Bay of Bengal has been rapid and efficient (near 100%) through time, and that periods of greater monsoon strength correspond to periods of higher rates of export of young, fresh (<100 years old) carbon from the Ganges-Brahmaputra basin to the coastal ocean. This finding demonstrates that the expansion of woody vegetation associated with the strengthening of the monsoon and the gradually warming temperatures following the Last Glacial Maximum provided a negative feedback on climate change; that is, more carbon was taken up by plants (reducing atmospheric CO2 levels) and that carbon was rapidly transferred to the Bay of Bengal, where it was buried and likely sequestered for thousands of years (or longer). Together, these findings highlight the importance of the Ganges-Brahmaputra system - and more broadly other highly erosive mountain systems - in helping to modulate climate over glacial-interglacial periods.

In addition to our primary scientific findings, this project financially supported three early career scientists (French, Hein, Galy) as they completed postdoctoral fellowships, set-up new state-of-the-art labs, and expanded fledging scientific programs, respectively. It also supported the training of one, and partial training of a second, undergraduate student from underserved populations through Woods Hole Partnership Education Program summer internships, and provided partial financial support for the training of one additional graduate and one undergraduate student at the Virginia Institute of Marine Science and College of William and Mary, respectively.
